"""
Builds calendar layout using Columns and Tables.
Usage:
python print_calendar.py [YEAR]
Example:
python print_calendar.py 2021
"""
import argparse
import calendar
from datetime import datetime
from typing import List, Tuple

from rich.align import Align
from rich import box
from rich.columns import Columns
from rich.console import Console
from rich.table import Table
from rich.text import Text


class CalendarStyler:
    """Handles styling logic for calendar days."""
    
    WEEKEND_INDICES = (5, 6)
    DEFAULT_DAY_STYLE = "magenta"
    WEEKEND_STYLE = "blue"
    TODAY_STYLE = "white on dark_red"
    
    def __init__(self, today_tuple: Tuple[int, int, int]):
        self._today_tuple = today_tuple
    
    def style_day(self, day: int, month: int, year: int, weekday_index: int) -> Text:
        """Apply appropriate styling to a calendar day."""
        day_text = str(day) if day else ""
        day_label = Text(day_text, style=self.DEFAULT_DAY_STYLE)
        
        if self._is_weekend(weekday_index):
            day_label.stylize(self.WEEKEND_STYLE)
        
        if self._is_today(day, month, year):
            day_label.stylize(self.TODAY_STYLE)
        
        return day_label
    
    def _is_weekend(self, weekday_index: int) -> bool:
        """Check if the given weekday index represents a weekend."""
        return weekday_index in self.WEEKEND_INDICES
    
    def _is_today(self, day: int, month: int, year: int) -> bool:
        """Check if the given date is today."""
        return day and (day, month, year) == self._today_tuple


class MonthTableBuilder:
    """Builds table representation for a single month."""
    
    MONTH_TITLE_STYLE = "green"
    TABLE_BOX_STYLE = box.SIMPLE_HEAVY
    
    def __init__(self, calendar_instance: calendar.Calendar, styler: CalendarStyler):
        self._calendar = calendar_instance
        self._styler = styler
    
    def build_month_table(self, year: int, month: int) -> Table:
        """Build a table for the specified month and year."""
        table = self._create_base_table(month, year)
        self._add_weekday_columns(table)
        self._populate_month_days(table, year, month)
        return table
    
    def _create_base_table(self, month: int, year: int) -> Table:
        """Create the base table with title and styling."""
        return Table(
            title=f"{calendar.month_name[month]} {year}",
            style=self.MONTH_TITLE_STYLE,
            box=self.TABLE_BOX_STYLE,
            padding=0,
        )
    
    def _add_weekday_columns(self, table: Table) -> None:
        """Add weekday header columns to the table."""
        for weekday in self._calendar.iterweekdays():
            weekday_name = calendar.day_name[weekday]
            table.add_column(f"{weekday_name:.3}", justify="right")
    
    def _populate_month_days(self, table: Table, year: int, month: int) -> None:
        """Populate the table with styled day cells."""
        month_days = self._calendar.monthdayscalendar(year, month)
        
        for week_days in month_days:
            styled_days = self._style_week_days(week_days, month, year)
            table.add_row(*styled_days)
    
    def _style_week_days(self, week_days: List[int], month: int, year: int) -> List[Text]:
        """Apply styling to all days in a week."""
        return [
            self._styler.style_day(day, month, year, index)
            for index, day in enumerate(week_days)
        ]


class CalendarRenderer:
    """Handles the rendering of the complete calendar."""
    
    def __init__(self, console: Console):
        self._console = console
    
    def render_year_calendar(self, year: int, month_tables: List[Table]) -> None:
        """Render the complete year calendar with all month tables."""
        aligned_tables = [Align.center(table) for table in month_tables]
        columns = Columns(aligned_tables, padding=1, expand=True)
        
        year_str = str(year)
        self._console.rule(year_str)
        self._console.print()
        self._console.print(columns)
        self._console.rule(year_str)


class CalendarPrinter:
    """Main class responsible for coordinating calendar printing."""
    
    MONTHS_IN_YEAR = range(1, 13)
    
    def __init__(self):
        self._console = Console()
        self._calendar = calendar.Calendar()
        self._renderer = CalendarRenderer(self._console)
    
    def print_calendar(self, year: int) -> None:
        """Print a calendar for the given year."""
        today_tuple = self._get_today_tuple()
        styler = CalendarStyler(today_tuple)
        table_builder = MonthTableBuilder(self._calendar, styler)
        
        month_tables = [
            table_builder.build_month_table(year, month)
            for month in self.MONTHS_IN_YEAR
        ]
        
        self._renderer.render_year_calendar(year, month_tables)
    
    def _get_today_tuple(self) -> Tuple[int, int, int]:
        """Get today's date as a tuple (day, month, year)."""
        today = datetime.today()
        return today.day, today.month, today.year


def print_calendar(year: int) -> None:
    """Print a calendar for a given year."""
    calendar_printer = CalendarPrinter()
    calendar_printer.print_calendar(year)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="Rich calendar")
    parser.add_argument("year", metavar="year", type=int)
    args = parser.parse_args()

    print_calendar(args.year)

"""
Builds calendar layout using Columns and Tables.
Usage:
python print_calendar.py [YEAR]
Example:
python print_calendar.py 2021
"""
import argparse
import calendar
from datetime import datetime
from typing import List, Tuple

from rich.align import Align
from rich import box
from rich.columns import Columns
from rich.console import Console
from rich.table import Table
from rich.text import Text


class CalendarStyler:
    """Handles styling logic for calendar days."""
    
    WEEKEND_INDICES = (5, 6)
    DEFAULT_DAY_STYLE = "magenta"
    WEEKEND_STYLE = "blue"
    TODAY_STYLE = "white on dark_red"
    
    def __init__(self, today_tuple: Tuple[int, int, int]):
        self._today_tuple = today_tuple
    
    def style_day(self, day: int, month: int, year: int, weekday_index: int) -> Text:
        """Apply appropriate styling to a calendar day."""
        day_text = str(day) if day else ""
        day_label = Text(day_text, style=self.DEFAULT_DAY_STYLE)
        
        if self._is_weekend(weekday_index):
            day_label.stylize(self.WEEKEND_STYLE)
        
        if self._is_today(day, month, year):
            day_label.stylize(self.TODAY_STYLE)
        
        return day_label
    
    def _is_weekend(self, weekday_index: int) -> bool:
        """Check if the given weekday index represents a weekend."""
        return weekday_index in self.WEEKEND_INDICES
    
    def _is_today(self, day: int, month: int, year: int) -> bool:
        """Check if the given date is today."""
        return day and (day, month, year) == self._today_tuple


class MonthTableBuilder:
    """Builds table representation for a single month."""
    
    MONTH_TITLE_STYLE = "green"
    TABLE_BOX_STYLE = box.SIMPLE_HEAVY
    
    def __init__(self, calendar_instance: calendar.Calendar, styler: CalendarStyler):
        self._calendar = calendar_instance
        self._styler = styler
    
    def build_month_table(self, year: int, month: int) -> Table:
        """Build a table for the specified month and year."""
        table = self._create_base_table(month, year)
        self._add_weekday_columns(table)
        self._populate_month_days(table, year, month)
        return table
    
    def _create_base_table(self, month: int, year: int) -> Table:
        """Create the base table with title and styling."""
        return Table(
            title=f"{calendar.month_name[month]} {year}",
            style=self.MONTH_TITLE_STYLE,
            box=self.TABLE_BOX_STYLE,
            padding=0,
        )
    
    def _add_weekday_columns(self, table: Table) -> None:
        """Add weekday header columns to the table."""
        for weekday in self._calendar.iterweekdays():
            weekday_name = calendar.day_name[weekday]
            table.add_column(f"{weekday_name:.3}", justify="right")
    
    def _populate_month_days(self, table: Table, year: int, month: int) -> None:
        """Populate the table with styled day cells."""
        for week_days in self._calendar.monthdayscalendar(year, month):
            styled_days = [
                self._styler.style_day(day, month, year, index)
                for index, day in enumerate(week_days)
            ]
            table.add_row(*styled_days)
    
    def _style_week_days(self, week_days: List[int], month: int, year: int) -> List[Text]:
        """Apply styling to all days in a week."""
        return [
            self._styler.style_day(day, month, year, index)
            for index, day in enumerate(week_days)
        ]


class CalendarRenderer:
    """Handles the rendering of the complete calendar."""
    
    def __init__(self, console: Console):
        self._console = console
    
    def render_year_calendar(self, year: int, month_tables: List[Table]) -> None:
        """Render the complete year calendar with all month tables."""
        aligned_tables = [Align.center(table) for table in month_tables]
        columns = Columns(aligned_tables, padding=1, expand=True)
        
        year_str = str(year)
        self._console.rule(year_str)
        self._console.print()
        self._console.print(columns)
        self._console.rule(year_str)


class CalendarPrinter:
    """Main class responsible for coordinating calendar printing."""
    
    MONTHS_IN_YEAR = range(1, 13)
    
    def __init__(self):
        self._console = Console()
        self._calendar = calendar.Calendar()
        self._renderer = CalendarRenderer(self._console)
    
    def print_calendar(self, year: int) -> None:
        """Print a calendar for the given year."""
        today_tuple = self._get_today_tuple()
        styler = CalendarStyler(today_tuple)
        table_builder = MonthTableBuilder(self._calendar, styler)
        
        month_tables = [
            table_builder.build_month_table(year, month)
            for month in self.MONTHS_IN_YEAR
        ]
        
        self._renderer.render_year_calendar(year, month_tables)
    
    def _get_today_tuple(self) -> Tuple[int, int, int]:
        """Get today's date as a tuple (day, month, year)."""
        today = datetime.today()
        return today.day, today.month, today.year


def print_calendar(year: int) -> None:
    """Print a calendar for a given year."""
    calendar_printer = CalendarPrinter()
    calendar_printer.print_calendar(year)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    parser = argparse.ArgumentParser(description="Rich calendar")
    parser.add_argument("year", metavar="year", type=int)
    args = parser.parse_args()

    print_calendar(args.year)

"""

This example demonstrates how to write a custom highlighter.

"""

from random import randint
from typing import TYPE_CHECKING

from rich import print
from rich.highlighter import Highlighter

if TYPE_CHECKING:
    from rich.text import Text


class ColorGenerator:
    """Generates random colors for text styling."""
    
    MIN_COLOR_VALUE = 16
    MAX_COLOR_VALUE = 255
    
    @classmethod
    def get_random_color(cls) -> str:
        """Generate a random color value within the valid range."""
        color_value = randint(cls.MIN_COLOR_VALUE, cls.MAX_COLOR_VALUE)
        return f"color({color_value})"


class RainbowHighlighter(Highlighter):
    """Highlighter that applies random colors to each character."""
    
    def __init__(self) -> None:
        super().__init__()
        self._color_generator = ColorGenerator()
    
    def highlight(self, text: "Text") -> "Text":
        """Apply rainbow coloring to each character in the text."""
        self._apply_rainbow_styling(text)
        return text
    
    def _apply_rainbow_styling(self, text: "Text") -> None:
        """Apply random color styling to each character position."""
        for character_index in range(len(text)):
            color_style = self._color_generator.get_random_color()
            text.stylize(color_style, character_index, character_index + 1)


def main() -> None:
    """Demonstrate rainbow highlighting functionality."""
    rainbow_highlighter = RainbowHighlighter()
    sample_text = "I must not fear. Fear is the mind-killer."
    print(rainbow_highlighter(sample_text))


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
else:
    # Maintain backward compatibility for direct usage
    rainbow = RainbowHighlighter()
    print(rainbow("I must not fear. Fear is the mind-killer."))

from __future__ import annotations

import collections.abc as cabc
import textwrap
from contextlib import contextmanager


class TextWrapper(textwrap.TextWrapper):
    def _handle_long_word(
        self,
        reversed_chunks: list[str],
        cur_line: list[str],
        cur_len: int,
        width: int,
    ) -> None:
        space_left = max(width - cur_len, 1)

        if self.break_long_words:
            last = reversed_chunks[-1]
            cut = last[:space_left]
            res = last[space_left:]
            cur_line.append(cut)
            reversed_chunks[-1] = res
        elif not cur_line:
            cur_line.append(reversed_chunks.pop())

    @contextmanager
    def extra_indent(self, indent: str) -> cabc.Iterator[None]:
        old_initial_indent = self.initial_indent
        old_subsequent_indent = self.subsequent_indent
        self.initial_indent += indent
        self.subsequent_indent += indent

        try:
            yield
        finally:
            self.initial_indent = old_initial_indent
            self.subsequent_indent = old_subsequent_indent

    def indent_only(self, text: str) -> str:
        lines = text.split('\n')
        if not lines:
            return text
        
        initial_indent = self.initial_indent
        subsequent_indent = self.subsequent_indent
        
        result = [initial_indent + lines[0]]
        result.extend(subsequent_indent + line for line in lines[1:])
        
        return '\n'.join(result)

            result.append(subsequent_indent + line)
        
        return '\n'.join(result)

"""
A rudimentary URL downloader (like wget or curl) to demonstrate Rich progress bars.
"""

import os
import os.path
import sys
import re
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor
import signal
from functools import partial
from threading import Event
from typing import Iterable, Optional, Any
from urllib.request import urlopen
from urllib.parse import urlparse
import html
import types

from rich.progress import (
    BarColumn,
    DownloadColumn,
    Progress,
    TaskID,
    TextColumn,
    TimeRemainingColumn,
    TransferSpeedColumn,
)

progress: Progress = Progress(
    TextColumn("[bold blue]{task.fields[filename]}", justify="right"),
    BarColumn(bar_width=None),
    "[progress.percentage]{task.percentage:>3.1f}%",
    "•",
    DownloadColumn(),
    "•",
    TransferSpeedColumn(),
    "•",
    TimeRemainingColumn(),
)


done_event: Event = Event()


def handle_sigint(signum: int, frame: Optional[types.FrameType]) -> None:
    done_event.set()


signal.signal(signal.SIGINT, handle_sigint)


def validate_url(url: str) -> bool:
    """Validate URL format and allowed schemes."""
    try:
        parsed = urlparse(url)
        # Only allow http and https schemes
        if parsed.scheme not in ('http', 'https'):
            return False
        # Ensure hostname is present
        if not parsed.netloc:
            return False
        return True
    except Exception:
        return False


def sanitize_filename(filename: str) -> str:
    """Sanitize filename to prevent path traversal and ensure valid filename."""
    if not filename or not isinstance(filename, str):
        return "download"
    
    # Remove path separators and dangerous characters
    filename = os.path.basename(filename)
    filename = re.sub(r'[<>:"/\\|?*\x00-\x1f]', '_', filename)
    
    # Remove leading/trailing dots and spaces
    filename = filename.strip('. ')
    
    # Ensure filename is not empty and not too long
    if not filename or len(filename) > 255:
        filename = "download"
    
    # Prevent reserved names on Windows
    reserved_names = {'CON', 'PRN', 'AUX', 'NUL', 'COM1', 'COM2', 'COM3', 'COM4', 
                     'COM5', 'COM6', 'COM7', 'COM8', 'COM9', 'LPT1', 'LPT2', 
                     'LPT3', 'LPT4', 'LPT5', 'LPT6', 'LPT7', 'LPT8', 'LPT9'}
    if filename.upper().split('.')[0] in reserved_names:
        filename = f"_{filename}"
    
    return filename


def validate_dest_path(dest_dir: str, filename: str) -> str:
    """Validate and construct safe destination path."""
    # Resolve and normalize paths
    dest_dir = os.path.abspath(dest_dir)
    dest_path = os.path.join(dest_dir, filename)
    dest_path = os.path.abspath(dest_path)
    
    # Ensure the destination is within the intended directory (prevent path traversal)
    if not dest_path.startswith(dest_dir + os.sep) and dest_path != dest_dir:
        raise ValueError("Invalid destination path")
    
    return dest_path


def copy_url(task_id: TaskID, url: str, path: str) -> None:
    """Copy data from a url to a local file."""
    try:
        # Escape URL for safe logging
        safe_url: str = html.escape(url)
        progress.console.log(f"Requesting {safe_url}")
        
        response = urlopen(url, timeout=30)
        
        # Handle missing Content-Length header
        content_length: Optional[str] = response.info().get("Content-length")
        if content_length:
            try:
                total_size: int = int(content_length)
                progress.update(task_id, total=total_size)
            except (ValueError, TypeError):
                pass  # Continue without total size if invalid
        
        # Create directory if it doesn't exist
        os.makedirs(os.path.dirname(path), exist_ok=True)
        
        with open(path, "wb") as dest_file:
            progress.start_task(task_id)
            for data in iter(partial(response.read, 32768), b""):
                dest_file.write(data)
                progress.update(task_id, advance=len(data))
                if done_event.is_set():
                    return
        
        # Escape path for safe logging
        safe_path: str = html.escape(path)
        progress.console.log(f"Downloaded {safe_path}")
        
    except Exception as e:
        safe_error: str = html.escape(str(e))
        progress.console.log(f"Error downloading {html.escape(url)}: {safe_error}")


def download(urls: Iterable[str], dest_dir: str) -> None:
    """Download multiple files to the given directory."""
    
    # Validate destination directory
    if not dest_dir or not isinstance(dest_dir, str):
        raise ValueError("Invalid destination directory")
    
    # Get max workers from environment or default to 4
    try:
        max_workers: int = int(os.getenv('DOWNLOADER_MAX_WORKERS', '4'))
        if max_workers <= 0 or max_workers > 50:  # Reasonable limits
            max_workers = 4
    except (ValueError, TypeError):
        max_workers = 4

    with progress:
        with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=max_workers) as pool:
            for url in urls:
                if not isinstance(url, str):
                    progress.console.log(f"Skipping invalid URL: {type(url)}")
                    continue
                
                # Validate URL
                if not validate_url(url):
                    safe_url: str = html.escape(url)
                    progress.console.log(f"Skipping invalid URL: {safe_url}")
                    continue
                
                # Extract and sanitize filename
                raw_filename: str = url.split("/")[-1]
                filename: str = sanitize_filename(raw_filename)
                
                try:
                    # Validate destination path
                    dest_path: str = validate_dest_path(dest_dir, filename)
                    
                    task_id: TaskID = progress.add_task("download", filename=filename, start=False)
                    pool.submit(copy_url, task_id, url, dest_path)
                    
                except ValueError as e:
                    safe_error: str = html.escape(str(e))
                    progress.console.log(f"Skipping URL due to path error: {safe_error}")
                    continue


if __name__ == "__main__":
    # Try with https://releases.ubuntu.com/noble/ubuntu-24.04-desktop-amd64.iso
    # and https://releases.ubuntu.com/noble/ubuntu-24.04-live-server-amd64.iso
    if sys.argv[1:]:
        try:
            download(sys.argv[1:], "./")
        except ValueError as e:
            print(f"Error: {e}")
            sys.exit(1)
    else:
        print("Usage:\n\tpython downloader.py URL1 URL2 URL3 (etc)")

#!/usr/bin/env python

# This is a shim to hopefully allow Github to detect the package, build is done with poetry

import setuptools
import re

def validate_package_name(name):
    """Validate package name follows PEP 508 naming conventions"""
    if not isinstance(name, str):
        raise ValueError("Package name must be a string")
    
    # PEP 508 compliant package name pattern
    pattern = r'^[A-Za-z0-9]([A-Za-z0-9._-]*[A-Za-z0-9])?$'
    if not re.match(pattern, name):
        raise ValueError("Invalid package name format")
    
    if len(name) > 214:  # PyPI package name limit
        raise ValueError("Package name too long")
    
    return name

if __name__ == "__main__":
    package_name = "rich"
    validated_name = validate_package_name(package_name)
    setuptools.setup(name=validated_name)

#!/usr/bin/env python
import os
import sys
from codecs import open
from typing import Dict, Any

from setuptools import setup


class PythonVersionChecker:
    """Handles Python version validation."""
    
    MINIMUM_VERSION = (3, 9)
    
    @classmethod
    def validate_version(cls) -> None:
        """Validate that Python version meets minimum requirements."""
        if sys.version_info[:2] < cls.MINIMUM_VERSION:
            error_message = cls._format_version_error_message()
            sys.stderr.write(error_message)
            sys.exit(1)
    
    @classmethod
    def _format_version_error_message(cls) -> str:
        """Format the version error message."""
        return """
==========================
Unsupported Python version
==========================
This version of Requests requires at least Python 3.9, but
you're trying to install it on Python {}.{}. To resolve this,
consider upgrading to a supported Python version.

If you can't upgrade your Python version, you'll need to
pin to an older version of Requests (<2.32.0).
""".format(*sys.version_info[:2])


class PublishCommandHandler:
    """Handles the publish command functionality."""
    
    @staticmethod
    def handle_publish_command() -> None:
        """Handle the publish command if specified."""
        if sys.argv[-1] == "publish":
            PublishCommandHandler._execute_publish_commands()
            sys.exit()
    
    @staticmethod
    def _execute_publish_commands() -> None:
        """Execute the publish commands."""
        os.system("python setup.py sdist bdist_wheel")
        os.system("twine upload dist/*")


class FileContentLoader:
    """Handles loading content from various files."""
    
    def __init__(self, base_directory: str):
        self.base_directory = base_directory
    
    def load_version_info(self) -> Dict[str, Any]:
        """Load version information from __version__.py file."""
        version_info = {}
        version_file_path = os.path.join(
            self.base_directory, "src", "requests", "__version__.py"
        )
        with open(version_file_path, "r", "utf-8") as file:
            exec(file.read(), version_info)
        return version_info
    
    def load_readme_content(self) -> str:
        """Load README content from README.md file."""
        readme_file_path = os.path.join(self.base_directory, "README.md")
        with open(readme_file_path, "r", "utf-8") as file:
            return file.read()


class SetupConfigurationBuilder:
    """Builds the setup configuration dictionary."""
    
    def __init__(self, version_info: Dict[str, Any], readme_content: str):
        self.version_info = version_info
        self.readme_content = readme_content
    
    def build_configuration(self) -> Dict[str, Any]:
        """Build the complete setup configuration."""
        return {
            "name": self.version_info["__title__"],
            "version": self.version_info["__version__"],
            "description": self.version_info["__description__"],
            "long_description": self.readme_content,
            "long_description_content_type": "text/markdown",
            "author": self.version_info["__author__"],
            "author_email": self.version_info["__author_email__"],
            "url": self.version_info["__url__"],
            "packages": ["requests"],
            "package_data": {"": ["LICENSE", "NOTICE"]},
            "package_dir": {"": "src"},
            "include_package_data": True,
            "python_requires": ">=3.9",
            "zip_safe": False,
            "install_requires": self._get_install_requires(),
            "tests_require": self._get_tests_require(),
            "extras_require": self._get_extras_require(),
            "license": self.version_info["__license__"],
            "classifiers": self._get_classifiers(),
            "project_urls": self._get_project_urls(),
        }
    
    def _get_install_requires(self) -> list[str]:
        """Get the list of required dependencies."""
        return [
            "charset_normalizer>=2,<4",
            "idna>=2.5,<4",
            "urllib3>=1.21.1,<3",
            "certifi>=2017.4.17",
        ]
    
    def _get_tests_require(self) -> list[str]:
        """Get the list of test dependencies."""
        return [
            "pytest-httpbin==2.1.0",
            "pytest-cov",
            "pytest-mock",
            "pytest-xdist",
            "PySocks>=1.5.6, !=1.5.7",
            "pytest>=3",
        ]
    
    def _get_extras_require(self) -> Dict[str, list[str]]:
        """Get the dictionary of extra requirements."""
        return {
            "security": [],
            "socks": ["PySocks>=1.5.6, !=1.5.7"],
            "use_chardet_on_py3": ["chardet>=3.0.2,<6"],
        }
    
    def _get_classifiers(self) -> list[str]:
        """Get the list of PyPI classifiers."""
        return [
            "Development Status :: 5 - Production/Stable",
            "Environment :: Web Environment",
            "Intended Audience :: Developers",
            "License :: OSI Approved :: Apache Software License",
            "Natural Language :: English",
            "Operating System :: OS Independent",
            "Programming Language :: Python",
            "Programming Language :: Python :: 3",
            "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.9",
            "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.10",
            "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.11",
            "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.12",
            "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.13",
            "Programming Language :: Python :: 3.14",
            "Programming Language :: Python :: 3 :: Only",
            "Programming Language :: Python :: Implementation :: CPython",
            "Programming Language :: Python :: Implementation :: PyPy",
            "Topic :: Internet :: WWW/HTTP",
            "Topic :: Software Development :: Libraries",
        ]
    
    def _get_project_urls(self) -> Dict[str, str]:
        """Get the project URLs dictionary."""
        return {
            "Documentation": "https://requests.readthedocs.io",
            "Source": "https://github.com/psf/requests",
        }


class SetupOrchestrator:
    """Orchestrates the entire setup process."""
    
    def __init__(self):
        self.base_directory = os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(__file__))
        self.file_loader = FileContentLoader(self.base_directory)
    
    def execute_setup(self) -> None:
        """Execute the complete setup process."""
        PythonVersionChecker.validate_version()
        PublishCommandHandler.handle_publish_command()
        
        version_info = self.file_loader.load_version_info()
        readme_content = self.file_loader.load_readme_content()
        
        config_builder = SetupConfigurationBuilder(version_info, readme_content)
        setup_configuration = config_builder.build_configuration()
        
        setup(**setup_configuration)


def main() -> None:
    """Main setup function."""
    orchestrator = SetupOrchestrator()
    orchestrator.execute_setup()


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

"""
Basic example to show how to print an traceback of an exception
"""
from typing import List, Tuple

from rich.console import Console

console = Console()


def divide_by(number: float, divisor: float) -> float:
    """Divide any number by zero."""
    # Will throw a ZeroDivisionError if divisor is 0
    result = number / divisor
    return result


def divide_all(divides: List[Tuple[float, float]]) -> None:
    """Do something impossible every day."""

    for number, divisor in divides:
        console.print(f"dividing {number} by {divisor}")
        try:
            result = divide_by(number, divisor)
        except Exception:
            console.print_exception(extra_lines=8, show_locals=True)
        else:
            console.print(f" = {result}")


DIVIDES = [
    (1000, 200),
    (10000, 500),
    (1, 0),
    (0, 1000000),
    (3.1427, 2),
    (888, 0),
    (2**32, 2**16),
]

divide_all(DIVIDES)

from typing import NamedTuple, Tuple


class ColorTriplet(NamedTuple):
    """The red, green, and blue components of a color."""

    red: int
    """Red component in 0 to 255 range."""
    green: int
    """Green component in 0 to 255 range."""
    blue: int
    """Blue component in 0 to 255 range."""

    @property
    def hex(self) -> str:
        """get the color triplet in CSS style."""
        red, green, blue = self
        return f"#{red:02x}{green:02x}{blue:02x}"

    @property
    def rgb(self) -> str:
        """The color in RGB format.

        Returns:
            str: An rgb color, e.g. ``"rgb(100,23,255)"``.
        """
        red, green, blue = self
        return f"rgb({red},{green},{blue})"

    @property
    def normalized(self) -> Tuple[float, float, float]:
        """Convert components into floats between 0 and 1.

        Returns:
            Tuple[float, float, float]: A tuple of three normalized colour components.
        """
        red, green, blue = self
        return red / 255.0, green / 255.0, blue / 255.0

import click
from typing import List, BinaryIO


class FileProcessor:
    """Handles file processing operations following Single Responsibility Principle."""
    
    CHUNK_SIZE = 1024
    
    def copy_files(self, input_files: List[BinaryIO], output_file: BinaryIO) -> None:
        """Copy data from multiple input files to a single output file."""
        for input_file in input_files:
            self._copy_single_file(input_file, output_file)
    
    def _copy_single_file(self, input_file: BinaryIO, output_file: BinaryIO) -> None:
        """Copy data from one input file to output file in chunks."""
        while True:
            chunk = input_file.read(self.CHUNK_SIZE)
            if not chunk:
                break
            output_file.write(chunk)
            output_file.flush()


@click.command()
@click.argument("input_files", type=click.File("rb"), nargs=-1)
@click.argument("output_file", type=click.File("wb"))
def cli(input_files: List[BinaryIO], output_file: BinaryIO) -> None:
    """This script works similar to the Unix `cat` command but it writes
    into a specific file (which could be the standard output as denoted by
    the ``-`` sign).

    \b
    Copy stdin to stdout:
        inout - -

    \b
    Copy foo.txt and bar.txt to stdout:
        inout foo.txt bar.txt -

    \b
    Write stdin into the file foo.txt
        inout - foo.txt
    """
    processor = FileProcessor()
    processor.copy_files(input_files, output_file)

            output_file.flush()


@click.command()
@click.argument("input_files", type=click.File("rb"), nargs=-1)
@click.argument("output_file", type=click.File("wb"))
def cli(input_files: List[BinaryIO], output_file: BinaryIO) -> None:
    """This script works similar to the Unix `cat` command but it writes
    into a specific file (which could be the standard output as denoted by
    the ``-`` sign).

    \b
    Copy stdin to stdout:
        inout - -

    \b
    Copy foo.txt and bar.txt to stdout:
        inout foo.txt bar.txt -

    \b
    Write stdin into the file foo.txt
        inout - foo.txt
    """
    processor = FileProcessor()
    processor.copy_files(input_files, output_file)

from typing import List, TypeVar, Protocol

T = TypeVar("T")


class StackProtocol(Protocol[T]):
    """Protocol defining stack operations."""
    
    def push(self, item: T) -> None:
        """Push an item onto the stack."""
        ...
    
    def top(self) -> T:
        """Get the top item from the stack."""
        ...


class Stack(List[T]):
    """A stack implementation extending the built-in list.
    
    Provides stack-specific operations (push, top) while maintaining
    all list functionality for backward compatibility.
    """

    @property
    def top(self) -> T:
        """Get the top item from the stack.
        
        Returns:
            The last item added to the stack.
            
        Raises:
            IndexError: If the stack is empty.
        """
        return self[-1]

    def push(self, item: T) -> None:
        """Push an item onto the stack.
        
        Args:
            item: The item to add to the top of the stack.
        """
        self.append(item)

from typing import List, TypeVar, Protocol, TYPE_CHECKING

T = TypeVar("T")

if TYPE_CHECKING:
    class StackProtocol(Protocol[T]):
        """Protocol defining stack operations."""
        
        def push(self, item: T) -> None:
            """Push an item onto the stack."""
            ...
        
        def top(self) -> T:
            """Get the top item from the stack."""
            ...
else:
    class StackProtocol:
        """Protocol defining stack operations."""
        pass


class Stack(List[T]):
    """A stack implementation extending the built-in list.
    
    Provides stack-specific operations (push, top) while maintaining
    all list functionality for backward compatibility.
    """

    @property
    def top(self) -> T:
        """Get the top item from the stack.
        
        Returns:
            The last item added to the stack.
            
        Raises:
            IndexError: If the stack is empty.
        """
        return self[-1]

    def push(self, item: T) -> None:
        """Push an item onto the stack.
        
        Args:
            item: The item to add to the top of the stack.
        """
        self.append(item)

from typing import NamedTuple


class ColorTriplet(NamedTuple):
    """The red, green, and blue components of a color."""

    red: int
    """Red component in 0 to 255 range."""
    green: int
    """Green component in 0 to 255 range."""
    blue: int
    """Blue component in 0 to 255 range."""

    @property
    def hex(self) -> str:
        """get the color triplet in CSS style."""
        red, green, blue = self
        return f"#{red:02x}{green:02x}{blue:02x}"

    @property
    def rgb(self) -> str:
        """The color in RGB format.

        Returns:
            str: An rgb color, e.g. ``"rgb(100,23,255)"``.
        """
        red, green, blue = self
        return f"rgb({red},{green},{blue})"

    @property
    def normalized(self):
        """Convert components into floats between 0 and 1.

        Returns:
            Tuple[float, float, float]: A tuple of three normalized colour components.
        """
        red, green, blue = self
        return red / 255.0, green / 255.0, blue / 255.0

class ColorTriplet(NamedTuple):
    """The red, green, and blue components of a color."""

    """Red component in 0 to 255 range."""
    green: int
    """Green component in 0 to 255 range."""
    blue: int
    """Blue component in 0 to 255 range."""

    @property
    def hex(self) -> str:
        """get the color triplet in CSS style."""
        red, green, blue = self
        return f"#{red:02x}{green:02x}{blue:02x}"

    @property
    def rgb(self) -> str:
        """The color in RGB format.

        Returns:
            str: An rgb color, e.g. ``"rgb(100,23,255)"``.
        """

        return f"rgb({red},{green},{blue})"

    def normalized(self) -> Tuple[float, float, float]:

"""
A very simple `ls` clone.

If your terminal supports hyperlinks you should be able to launch files by clicking the filename
(usually with cmd / ctrl).

"""

import os
import sys

from rich import print
from rich.columns import Columns
from rich.text import Text

try:
    root_path = sys.argv[1]
except IndexError:
    print("Usage: python listdir.py DIRECTORY")
else:

    def make_filename_text(filename):
        path = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(root_path, filename))
        text = Text(filename, style="bold blue" if os.path.isdir(path) else "default")
        text.stylize(f"link file://{path}")
        text.highlight_regex(r"\..*?$", "bold")
        return text

    filenames = [
        filename for filename in os.listdir(root_path) if not filename.startswith(".")
    ]
    filenames.sort(key=lambda filename: filename.lower())
    filename_text = [make_filename_text(filename) for filename in filenames]
    columns = Columns(filename_text, equal=True, column_first=True)
    print(columns)

"""
Demonstrates export console output
"""

from rich.console import Console
from rich.table import Table

console = Console(record=True)


def print_table():
    table = Table(title="Star Wars Movies")

    table.add_column("Released", style="cyan", no_wrap=True)
    table.add_column("Title", style="magenta")
    table.add_column("Box Office", justify="right", style="green")

    table.add_row("Dec 20, 2019", "Star Wars: The Rise of Skywalker", "$952,110,690")
    table.add_row("May 25, 2018", "Solo: A Star Wars Story", "$393,151,347")
    table.add_row("Dec 15, 2017", "Star Wars Ep. V111: The Last Jedi", "$1,332,539,889")
    table.add_row("Dec 16, 2016", "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story", "$1,332,439,889")

    console.print(table)


# Prints table
print_table()

# Get console output as text
file1 = "table_export_plaintext.txt"
text = console.export_text()
with open(file1, "w") as file:
    file.write(text)
print(f"Exported console output as plain text to {file1}")

# Calling print_table again because console output buffer
# is flushed once export function is called
print_table()

# Get console output as html
# use clear=False so output is not flushed after export
file2 = "table_export_html.html"
html = console.export_html(clear=False)
with open(file2, "w") as file:
    file.write(html)
print(f"Exported console output as html to {file2}")

# Export text output to table_export.txt
file3 = "table_export_plaintext2.txt"
console.save_text(file3, clear=False)
print(f"Exported console output as plain text to {file3}")

# Export html output to table_export.html
file4 = "table_export_html2.html"
console.save_html(file4)
print(f"Exported console output as html to {file4}")

"""
Demonstration of Console.screen() 
"""

from time import sleep
from typing import Protocol

from rich.align import Align
from rich.console import Console, RenderableType
from rich.panel import Panel


class ScreenDisplayProtocol(Protocol):
    """Protocol for screen display operations."""
    
    def display_message(self, message: str, duration: float) -> None:
        """Display a message on screen for specified duration."""
        ...


class PanicMessageDisplay:
    """Handles the display of panic messages on console screen."""
    
    def __init__(self, console: Console) -> None:
        self._console = console
        self._screen_style = "bold white on red"
        self._message_duration = 5.0
    
    def _create_centered_message(self, message: str) -> RenderableType:
        """Create a centered, blinking message."""
        formatted_message = f"[blink]{message}[/blink]"
        return Align.center(formatted_message, vertical="middle")
    
    def _create_message_panel(self, content: RenderableType) -> Panel:
        """Create a panel containing the message content."""
        return Panel(content)
    
    def display_message(self, message: str, duration: float = None) -> None:
        """Display a panic message on screen for specified duration."""
        display_duration = duration if duration is not None else self._message_duration
        
        with self._console.screen(style=self._screen_style) as screen:
            centered_text = self._create_centered_message(message)
            message_panel = self._create_message_panel(centered_text)
            screen.update(message_panel)
            sleep(display_duration)


def main() -> None:
    """Main function to demonstrate screen display functionality."""
    console = Console()
    display = PanicMessageDisplay(console)
    display.display_message("Don't Panic!")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

"""Same as the table_movie.py but uses Live to update"""
import time
from contextlib import contextmanager

from rich import box
from rich.align import Align
from rich.console import Console
from rich.live import Live
from rich.table import Table
from rich.text import Text

TABLE_DATA = [
    [
        "May 25, 1977",
        "Star Wars Ep. [b]IV[/]: [i]A New Hope",
        "$11,000,000",
        "$1,554,475",
        "$775,398,007",
    ],
    [
        "May 21, 1980",
        "Star Wars Ep. [b]V[/]: [i]The Empire Strikes Back",
        "$23,000,000",
        "$4,910,483",
        "$547,969,004",
    ],
    [
        "May 25, 1983",
        "Star Wars Ep. [b]VI[/b]: [i]Return of the Jedi",
        "$32,500,000",
        "$23,019,618",
        "$475,106,177",
    ],
    [
        "May 19, 1999",
        "Star Wars Ep. [b]I[/b]: [i]The Phantom Menace",
        "$115,000,000",
        "$64,810,870",
        "$1,027,044,677",
    ],
    [
        "May 16, 2002",
        "Star Wars Ep. [b]II[/b]: [i]Attack of the Clones",
        "$115,000,000",
        "$80,027,814",
        "$656,695,615",
    ],
    [
        "May 19, 2005",
        "Star Wars Ep. [b]III[/b]: [i]Revenge of the Sith",
        "$115,500,000",
        "$380,270,577",
        "$848,998,877",
    ],
]

console = Console()

BEAT_TIME = 0.04


@contextmanager
def beat(length: int = 1) -> None:
    yield
    time.sleep(length * BEAT_TIME)


table = Table(show_footer=False)
table_centered = Align.center(table)

console.clear()

with Live(table_centered, console=console, screen=False, refresh_per_second=4):
    with beat(10):
        table.add_column("Release Date", no_wrap=True)

    with beat(10):
        table.add_column("Title", Text.from_markup("[b]Total", justify="right"))

    with beat(10):
        table.add_column("Budget", "[u]$412,000,000", no_wrap=True)

    with beat(10):
        table.add_column("Opening Weekend", "[u]$577,703,455", no_wrap=True)

    with beat(10):
        table.add_column("Box Office", "[u]$4,331,212,357", no_wrap=True)

    with beat(10):
        table.title = "Star Wars Box Office"

    with beat(10):
        table.title = (
            "[not italic]:popcorn:[/] Star Wars Box Office [not italic]:popcorn:[/]"
        )

    with beat(10):
        table.caption = "Made with Rich"

    with beat(10):
        table.caption = "Made with [b]Rich[/b]"

    with beat(10):
        table.caption = "Made with [b magenta not dim]Rich[/]"

    for row in TABLE_DATA:
        with beat(10):
            table.add_row(*row)

    with beat(10):
        table.show_footer = True

    with beat(10):
        for i in range(2, 5):
            table.columns[i].justify = "right"

    with beat(10):
        table.columns[2].header_style = "bold red"
        table.columns[3].header_style = "bold green"
        table.columns[4].header_style = "bold blue"

    with beat(10):
        table.columns[2].style = "red"
        table.columns[3].style = "green"
        table.columns[4].style = "blue"

    with beat(10):
        table.columns[0].style = "cyan"
        table.columns[0].header_style = "bold cyan"

    with beat(10):
        table.columns[1].style = "magenta"
        table.columns[1].header_style = "bold magenta"

    with beat(10):
        table.columns[2].footer_style = "bright_red"
        table.columns[3].footer_style = "bright_green"
        table.columns[4].footer_style = "bright_blue"

    with beat(10):
        table.row_styles = ["none", "dim"]

    with beat(10):
        table.border_style = "bright_yellow"

    for box_style in [
        box.SQUARE,
        box.MINIMAL,
        box.SIMPLE,
        box.SIMPLE_HEAD,
    ]:
        with beat(10):
            table.box = box_style

    with beat(10):
        table.pad_edge = False

    original_width = console.measure(table).maximum

    for width in range(original_width, console.width, 2):
        with beat(1):
            table.width = width

    for width in range(console.width, original_width, -2):
        with beat(1):
            table.width = width

    for width in range(original_width, 90, -2):
        with beat(1):
            table.width = width

    for width in range(90, original_width + 1, 2):
        with beat(1):
            table.width = width

    with beat(2):
        table.width = None

        table.border_style = "bright_yellow"

        box.SQUARE,
        box.MINIMAL,
        box.SIMPLE,
        box.SIMPLE_HEAD,
    ]:
        with beat(10):
            table.box = box_style

    with beat(10):
        table.pad_edge = False

    original_width = console.measure(table).maximum

    for width in range(original_width, console.width, 2):

            table.width = width

    for width in range(console.width, original_width, -2):
        with beat(1):
            table.width = width

            table.width = width

    for width in range(90, original_width + 1, 2):
        with beat(1):
            table.width = width

    with beat(2):
        table.width = None

"""
Basic example to show how to print an traceback of an exception
"""
from typing import List, Tuple

from rich.console import Console

console = Console()


def divide_by(number: float, divisor: float) -> float:
    """Divide any number by zero."""
    # Will throw a ZeroDivisionError if divisor is 0
    result = number / divisor
    return result


def divide_all(divides: List[Tuple[float, float]]) -> None:
    """Do something impossible every day."""

    for number, divisor in divides:
        console.print(f"dividing {number} by {divisor}")
        try:
            result = divide_by(number, divisor)
        except Exception:
            console.print_exception(extra_lines=8, show_locals=True)
        else:
            console.print(f" = {result}")


if __name__ == "__main__":
    DIVIDES = [
        (1000, 200),
        (10000, 500),
        (1, 0),
        (0, 1000000),
        (3.1427, 2),
        (888, 0),
        (2**32, 2**16),
    ]

    divide_all(DIVIDES)

"""
Demonstrates how to display a tree of files / directories with the Tree renderable.
"""

import os
import pathlib
import sys
from typing import List

from rich import print
from rich.filesize import decimal
from rich.markup import escape
from rich.text import Text
from rich.tree import Tree


def validate_directory_path(path_str: str) -> pathlib.Path:
    """Validate and normalize directory path to prevent path traversal attacks."""
    if not path_str or not isinstance(path_str, str):
        raise ValueError("Invalid directory path provided")
    
    # Remove any null bytes
    path_str = path_str.replace('\x00', '')
    
    # Resolve the path to prevent path traversal
    try:
        resolved_path = pathlib.Path(path_str).resolve()
    except (OSError, ValueError) as e:
        raise ValueError(f"Invalid path: {e}")
    
    # Check if path exists and is a directory
    if not resolved_path.exists():
        raise ValueError(f"Directory does not exist: {resolved_path}")
    
    if not resolved_path.is_dir():
        raise ValueError(f"Path is not a directory: {resolved_path}")
    
    # Check if path is readable
    if not os.access(resolved_path, os.R_OK):
        raise ValueError(f"Directory is not readable: {resolved_path}")
    
    return resolved_path


def walk_directory(directory: pathlib.Path, tree: Tree) -> None:
    """Recursively build a Tree with directory contents."""
    try:
        # Sort dirs first then by filename
        paths: List[pathlib.Path] = sorted(
            directory.iterdir(),
            key=lambda path: (path.is_file(), path.name.lower()),
        )
    except (OSError, PermissionError):
        # Skip directories that cannot be read
        return
    
    for path in paths:
        try:
            # Remove hidden files
            if path.name.startswith("."):
                continue
            
            # Additional validation to prevent issues with special characters
            safe_name = escape(path.name)
            
            if path.is_dir():
                style: str = "dim" if path.name.startswith("__") else ""
                # Double escape the path name for security
                branch: Tree = tree.add(
                    f"[bold magenta]:open_file_folder: [link file://{escape(str(path))}]{safe_name}",
                    style=style,
                    guide_style=style,
                )
                walk_directory(path, branch)
            else:
                text_filename: Text = Text(safe_name, "green")
                text_filename.highlight_regex(r"\..*$", "bold red")
                text_filename.stylize(f"link file://{escape(str(path))}")
                try:
                    file_size: int = path.stat().st_size
                    text_filename.append(f" ({decimal(file_size)})", "blue")
                except (OSError, PermissionError):
                    # If we can't get file size, skip adding it
                    pass
                icon: str = "🐍 " if path.suffix == ".py" else "📄 "
                tree.add(Text(icon) + text_filename)
        except (OSError, PermissionError):
            # Skip files/directories that cannot be accessed
            continue


try:
    if len(sys.argv) < 2:
        raise IndexError("No directory argument provided")
    
    directory_path: pathlib.Path = validate_directory_path(sys.argv[1])
except (IndexError, ValueError) as e:
    print(f"[b]Usage:[/] python tree.py <DIRECTORY>")
    if isinstance(e, ValueError):
        print(f"[red]Error:[/] {e}")
else:
    tree: Tree = Tree(
        f":open_file_folder: [link file://{escape(str(directory_path))}]{escape(str(directory_path))}",
        guide_style="bold bright_blue",
    )
    walk_directory(directory_path, tree)
    print(tree)

from __future__ import annotations

import os
import typing as t
from datetime import timedelta

from .cli import AppGroup
from .globals import current_app
from .helpers import send_from_directory
from .sansio.blueprints import Blueprint as SansioBlueprint
from .sansio.blueprints import BlueprintSetupState as BlueprintSetupState  # noqa
from .sansio.scaffold import _sentinel

if t.TYPE_CHECKING:  # pragma: no cover
    from .wrappers import Response


class Blueprint(SansioBlueprint):
    def __init__(
        self,
        name: str,
        import_name: str,
        static_folder: str | os.PathLike[str] | None = None,
        static_url_path: str | None = None,
        template_folder: str | os.PathLike[str] | None = None,
        url_prefix: str | None = None,
        subdomain: str | None = None,
        url_defaults: dict[str, t.Any] | None = None,
        root_path: str | None = None,
        cli_group: str | None = _sentinel,  # type: ignore
    ) -> None:
        super().__init__(
            name,
            import_name,
            static_folder,
            static_url_path,
            template_folder,
            url_prefix,
            subdomain,
            url_defaults,
            root_path,
            cli_group,
        )

        #: The Click command group for registering CLI commands for this
        #: object. The commands are available from the ``flask`` command
        #: once the application has been discovered and blueprints have
        #: been registered.
        self.cli = AppGroup()

        # Set the name of the Click group in case someone wants to add
        # the app's commands to another CLI tool.
        self.cli.name = self.name

from __future__ import annotations

import typing as t

from . import typing as ft
from .globals import current_app
from .globals import request

F = t.TypeVar("F", bound=t.Callable[..., t.Any])

http_method_funcs = frozenset(
    ["get", "post", "head", "options", "delete", "put", "trace", "patch"]
)


class View:
    """Subclass this class and override :meth:`dispatch_request` to
    create a generic class-based view. Call :meth:`as_view` to create a
    view function that creates an instance of the class with the given
    arguments and calls its ``dispatch_request`` method with any URL
    variables.

    See :doc:`views` for a detailed guide.

    .. code-block:: python

        class Hello(View):
            init_every_request = False

            def dispatch_request(self, name):
                return f"Hello, {name}!"

        app.add_url_rule(
            "/hello/<name>", view_func=Hello.as_view("hello")
        )

    Set :attr:`methods` on the class to change what methods the view
    accepts.

    Set :attr:`decorators` on the class to apply a list of decorators to
    the generated view function. Decorators applied to the class itself
    will not be applied to the generated view function!

    Set :attr:`init_every_request` to ``False`` for efficiency, unless
    you need to store request-global data on ``self``.
    """

    #: The methods this view is registered for. Uses the same default
    #: (``["GET", "HEAD", "OPTIONS"]``) as ``route`` and
    #: ``add_url_rule`` by default.
    methods: t.ClassVar[t.Collection[str] | None] = None

    #: Control whether the ``OPTIONS`` method is handled automatically.
    #: Uses the same default (``True``) as ``route`` and
    #: ``add_url_rule`` by default.
    provide_automatic_options: t.ClassVar[bool | None] = None

    #: A list of decorators to apply, in order, to the generated view
    #: function. Remember that ``@decorator`` syntax is applied bottom
    #: to top, so the first decorator in the list would be the bottom
    #: decorator.
    #:
    #: .. versionadded:: 0.8
    decorators: t.ClassVar[list[t.Callable[[F], F]]] = []

    #: Create a new instance of this view class for every request by
    #: default. If a view subclass sets this to ``False``, the same
    #: instance is used for every request.
    #:
    #: A single instance is more efficient, especially if complex setup
    #: is done during init. However, storing data on ``self`` is no
    #: longer safe across requests, and :data:`~flask.g` should be used
    #: instead.
    #:
    #: .. versionadded:: 2.2
    init_every_request: t.ClassVar[bool] = True

    def dispatch_request(self) -> ft.ResponseReturnValue:
        """The actual view function behavior. Subclasses must override
        this and return a valid response. Any variables from the URL
        rule are passed as keyword arguments.
        """
        raise NotImplementedError()

    @classmethod
    def as_view(
        cls, name: str, *class_args: t.Any, **class_kwargs: t.Any
    ) -> ft.RouteCallable:
        """Convert the class into a view function that can be registered
        for a route.

        By default, the generated view will create a new instance of the
        view class for every request and call its
        :meth:`dispatch_request` method. If the view class sets
        :attr:`init_every_request` to ``False``, the same instance will
        be used for every request.

        Except for ``name``, all other arguments passed to this method
        are forwarded to the view class ``__init__`` method.

        .. versionchanged:: 2.2
            Added the ``init_every_request`` class attribute.
        """
        if cls.init_every_request:

            def view(**kwargs: t.Any) -> ft.ResponseReturnValue:
                self = view.view_class(  # type: ignore[attr-defined]
                    *class_args, **class_kwargs
                )
                return current_app.ensure_sync(self.dispatch_request)(**kwargs)  # type: ignore[no-any-return]

        else:
            self = cls(*class_args, **class_kwargs)

            def view(**kwargs: t.Any) -> ft.ResponseReturnValue:
                return current_app.ensure_sync(self.dispatch_request)(**kwargs)  # type: ignore[no-any-return]

        if cls.decorators:
            view.__name__ = name
            view.__module__ = cls.__module__
            for decorator in cls.decorators:
                view = decorator(view)

        # We attach the view class to the view function for two reasons:
        # first of all it allows us to easily figure out what class-based
        # view this thing came from, secondly it's also used for instantiating
        # the view class so you can actually replace it with something else
        # for testing purposes and debugging.
        view.view_class = cls  # type: ignore
        view.__name__ = name
        view.__doc__ = cls.__doc__
        view.__module__ = cls.__module__
        view.methods = cls.methods  # type: ignore
        view.provide_automatic_options = cls.provide_automatic_options  # type: ignore
        return view


class MethodView(View):
    """Dispatches request methods to the corresponding instance methods.
    For example, if you implement a ``get`` method, it will be used to
    handle ``GET`` requests.

    This can be useful for defining a REST API.

    :attr:`methods` is automatically set based on the methods defined on
    the class.

    See :doc:`views` for a detailed guide.

    .. code-block:: python

        class CounterAPI(MethodView):
            def get(self):
                return str(session.get("counter", 0))

            def post(self):
                session["counter"] = session.get("counter", 0) + 1
                return redirect(url_for("counter"))

        app.add_url_rule(
            "/counter", view_func=CounterAPI.as_view("counter")
        )
    """

    def __init_subclass__(cls, **kwargs: t.Any) -> None:
        super().__init_subclass__(**kwargs)

        if "methods" not in cls.__dict__:
            methods = set()

            for base in cls.__bases__:
                if getattr(base, "methods", None):
                    methods.update(base.methods)  # type: ignore[attr-defined]

            for key in http_method_funcs:
                if hasattr(cls, key):
                    methods.add(key.upper())

            if methods:
                cls.methods = methods

    def dispatch_request(self, **kwargs: t.Any) -> ft.ResponseReturnValue:
        meth = getattr(self, request.method.lower(), None)

        # If the request method is HEAD and we don't have a handler for it
        # retry with GET.
        if meth is None and request.method == "HEAD":
            meth = getattr(self, "get", None)

        assert meth is not None, f"Unimplemented method {request.method!r}"
        return current_app.ensure_sync(meth)(**kwargs)  # type: ignore[no-any-return]
